scenarioDescription:
The GJ 832 Exoplanetary System


Overview

GJ 832 is a star with 0.45 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.44 times its radius. It is located 16.19 light years away from the solar system.

GJ 832 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the GJ 832 system


GJ 832 b

GJ 832 b was discovered by the Anglo-Australian Telescope observatory, in 2009-01, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 3.56 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of GJ 832 b is 216.240 times the mass of Earth. The radius of GJ 832 b is 14.000 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, GJ 832 b is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.


GJ 832 c

GJ 832 c was discovered by the Multiple Observatories observatory, in 2014-08, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.16 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of GJ 832 c is 5.406 times the mass of Earth. The radius of GJ 832 c is 2.180 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, GJ 832 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanetary system GJ 832, which contains 2 exoplanets and was discovered by the Anglo-Australian Telescope.
name: GJ 832 - System With 2 Exoplanets
